JAMISON:Â  For those who have never heard of Sinon.JS, what is it? CHRISTIAN:Â  Sinon.JS is a stubbing and mocking library which means that when you're writing automated tests for your JavaScript, Sinon provides a tool kit to help you test functions and callbacks and stuff like that, to track how they're being used throughout the system. And then, it also provides some utilities to test asynchronous stuff through timers, like Set Time Out and Set Interval and those kinds of things. And it also has a fake XMLHttpRequest implementation. So, it allows you to test your client side JavaScript completely decoupled from the server and it gives you an API to mimic the role of the server in your tests. So, you can focus a test on how the client side reacts to various kind of behavior from the server. JAMISON:Â  So, you talked about stubbing and mocking. And I think, that means we have to get into the hairy discussion of the difference between stubs and mocks? MERRICK:Â  And spies. JAMISON:Â  And spies, yeah. Do you want to explain that a little bit? CHRISTIAN:Â  Sure. I can explain my take on it because I know there are more than just mine. MERRICK:Â  Sure. CHRISTIAN:Â  I'm using the terminology pretty much like Martin Fowler did and he has a famous article called â€˜Spies are Not Mocksâ€™ or something like that. So, the basic principle implemented in Sinon is that a spy is a function that just records information about how itâ€™s being used. If you call it, it sets a flag, called and it counts how many times itâ€™s been called, what kind of argument you cast into it and so on. And basically, thatâ€™s all it does. And then, a stub builds upon that concept but allowing you to also control what it does. So, you can create a stub and then you get a function object that will record everything just like a spy. And then, you can tell it to return certain values or if it receives these arguments, then throw an exception and so on. And then a mock builds upon that again where you can also build in expectations. So, you can tell the mocks that. So, if your call more than two times, throw an exception immediately. Thatâ€™s the rough cut of it, I think. JAMISON:Â  Thatâ€™s amazing. I guess I misunderstood what stubs were. I thought stubs were just basic dumb things that you just specify like a dummy return value for a function or a dummy value for an object or something. Is there a technical name for that? CHRISTIAN:Â  Thatâ€™s what I typically use the Sinon stubs for. But they also take on the spy [crosstalk] JAMISON:Â  And they give you more than that. CHRISTIAN:Â  Yes. MERRICK:Â  Would say Sinon does spy for that, in particular values? CHRISTIAN:Â  It depends on what you're using it for. Does that mean I'm doing it wrong? Is that just a hump I have to get over? Or do you have any suggestions to avoid that feeling? CHRISTIAN:Â  It probably means that something is not the way it should be. Typically, the way I use spies and stubs is supposedly to test the communication between objects or functions or whatever. In some cases, I would think that youâ€™ll end up re-implementing logic if your test is too big, if you're trying to achieve too many things at a test. CHRISTIAN:Â  Yeah. MERRICK:Â  Yeah. CHRISTIAN:Â  Typically, if you have some API that takes in a callback of some sort, then you can set up one test that says, â€œWhat happens if this callback returns the number 42?â€ And the next test can be, â€œWhat happens if this function throws an error?â€ But you have to split them up like that because if you donâ€™t, then youâ€™ll end up, like you said, re-implementing logic within your tests. Or you can actually specify that the properties have to have these values as well, right? CHRISTIAN:Â  Yeah. MERRICK:Â  So, like one of the places that I've been bitten a bunch before is verifying a call that came in with a callback. And I had access to the callback, but I ended up wrapping that callback in like a jQueryâ€™s proxy to make sure that it was bound correctly to the right context. So, having the ability to match just by, â€œHey, itâ€™s just got to be R function,â€ is just absolutely huge for me. CHRISTIAN:Â  Yeah. You could do it before too because you always have access to the arguments. So, you could do a type of check but itâ€™s really kind of verbose and ugly. So, I really liked the Matchers because they allow you to be a little bit more descriptive about what you're trying to achieve. It reads a lot better, I think. And method A internally calls method B. How do you feel about stubbing out method B just when you're testing method A so you do not actually test method B as well? Are you for that or against that? And the reasons why? CHRISTIAN:Â  I think Iâ€™d have to say that I'm, in principle, against that because I usually never stub out methods on the object that I'm testing. And the reason for that is that if you have a method A thatâ€™s calling method B on the same object, and you're stubbing out method B, then really, the test is very implementation specific. So, the fact that itâ€™s calling another function on the same object is really an implementation detail. Itâ€™s not part of its public API. So, Iâ€™d say that in a situation like that, if you have a need to do that, maybe thatâ€™s a signal that your design can be improved somehow. JOE:Â  Cool. I like that answer. Itâ€™s probably still not as great as in like -- I think that in the Ruby community, there's been a lot of focus on testing. CHRISTIAN:Â  Yeah, sure. So, I do both things, I think. And thatâ€™s actually kind of easy if you have that thought in your head as you're writing the code.
